metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Advanced "lab-on-a-chip" to detect viruses -Current challenges and future perspectives Advanced "lab-on-a-chip" to detect viruses -current challenges and future perspectives 1 2

abstract.text: Please cite this article as: Zhuang, J., Yin, J., Lv, S., Wang, B., Mu, Y., Advanced "lab-on-a-chip" to detect viruses -Current challenges and future perspectives, Biosensors and Bioelectronics (2020), doi: https://doi.
Massive viral outbreaks draw attention to viruses that have not been thoroughly studied or understood.

In recent decades, microfluidic chips, known as "lab-on-a-chip", appears as a promising tool for the 21 detection of viruses. Here, we review the development of microfluidic chips that could be used in 22 response to viral detection, specifically for viruses involved in more recent outbreaks. The advantages 23 as well as the disadvantages of microfluidic systems are discussed and analyzed. We also propose ideas 24 for future development of these microfluidic chips and we expect this advanced technology to be used 25 in the future for viral outbreaks.

4 minutes) and accurate (as low as 1 copy) detection for EBOV at POC. However, some chips lack 131 sample preparation or require additional instrumentation, which is not suitable in resource-limited 132 settings for POC. Moreover, due to the high contagious rate and characteristics of the multiple EBOV 133 subtypes, low-cost multiplex detection chips should be developed.

HIV is a single-stranded RNA virus that results in acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) 136 (Watts et al. 2009 ). HIV attacks T lymphocytes and integrates into the chromosomes of its host, which 137 in turn leads to defects in the human immune system causing irreparable damage to the body (Druce et simultaneously. This chip meets serological requirements and detects HIV RNA as low as 10 3 viral 166 particles/ml from saliva or blood.
Paper-based microfluidics is also an effective tool for HIV detection. Zhao

Moreover, rapid and ongoing evolution of influenza viruses will make this even more challenging.

In recent years, microfluidics has also shown to be an effective tool for the early diagnosis of (Figure 7 A ) . This strategy used bead beating and heating procedures to 303 obtain stable RNA directly from whole blood, which could be used to detect viruses. In this system, 304 direct buffer was used to extract RNA from whole blood and obtain a LOD of 10 2 PFU/200 μL in less 305 than 1 hour. Yin et al (Yin et al. 2020 ) reported a microfluidic system that integrated RNA extraction 306 and multiplex PCR to detect four DENV serotypes (Figure 7 B ). In this system, chitosan-modified 307 paper chip to extra RNA and on-chip PCR product was detected using a membrane sensor. This system

Detection reagents were prestored into the chip and the freeze-dried reagents were kept in 2−8 °C for 6 377 months in the disc chip. Moreover, the separation step of plasma or serum is avoided since it is directly 378 detected from whole blood. This system can detect 10 2 copies/mL HBV DNA in ~48 minutes from 500 379 μL of whole blood. Our group also proposed a digital isothermal chip for the quantitative detection of will give more precise results.

In addition, the integration of sample preparation with detection is important especially for 420 nucleic acid-based detection methods (Yin et al. 2019 ). However, very few studies have been able to 421 integrate virus sample preparation into chips. Integrated sample preparation will reduce testing time,
improve accuracy and minimize labor. Moreover, sample-in-answer-out is the ideal detection process.

Therefore, sample preparation should be considered in a single chip. Whether Lab-on-a-chip is used in 424 the clinic or the home, sample preparation integration is necessary. In addition, affordable and 425 user-friendly qualities should be considered especially for POC in resource-limited settings. Automated

and high-throughput microfluidics should also be considered. Therefore, additional sample preparation 427 methods should be tested and integrated into chips that will be used for virus outbreaks. chip is further combined with the "Biological mobile phone", "Mobile detection station", or "Artificial
Intelligence"，its potential for virus detection will be extended even further.

In the future, microfluidic products that meet the criteria for POC proposed by WHO including (1) 478 being affordable to those at risk of infection, containing (2) high sensitivity, (3) high specificity, (4) 479 user-friendly capabilities, being (5) rapid and robust, (6) equipment free, and (7)

FIGREF0.text: et al. 2016), and mortality (Campos et al. 2015). Viruses have the ability to 46 rapidly evolve and transmit through multiple modes such as the respiratory tract (Mazur et al. 2015; 47 109 microfluidic platform to extract and capture EBOV RNA using a photocleavable capture probe. This 110 chip has the ability to perform 80 assays in parallel and its analytical method contains a LOD of 800 111 aM. Qin et al (Qin et al. 2019) proposed an automated and multiplexing system to detect EBOV RNA 112 (Figure 3 A). This system can complete 24 assays while using use Cas13a to generate fluorescent 113reporter RNAs resulting in a LOD of 20 pfu/mL from 10 μL EBOV RNA within 5 minutes.

FIGREF1.text: 114 There are five types of EBOV including the Bundibugyo Ebola virus (BDBV), Reston virus 115 (RESTV), Zaire Ebola virus (ZEBOV), Tai Forest Ebola virus (TAFV) and Sudan Ebola virus (SUDV) 116 (Taniguchi et al. 2012). Four (EBOV, SUDV, BDBV, TAFV) of the five subtypes are extremely severe 117 and detrimental to humans (Khan et al. 2015). It is necessary to study microfluidic system capabilities 118 for the detection of various EBOV types. Magro et al also developed a multiplex paper chip to detect 119 three types of EBOV based on RPA (Magro et al. 2017) (Figure 3 B). Piraino et al (Piraino et al. 2016) 120 developed a microfluidic chip that combined digital and analog technologies. This chip contains a high 121 dynamic range and can simultaneously detect three types of EBOV with a LOD of 1pM from 5 μL of 122 serum. Brangel et al(Brangel et al. 2018) reported a paper and smartphone-based platform to detect IgG 123 antibodies against the virus in sera. Detection results testing 90 survivors and 31 uninfected individuals 124 revealed 100 % sensitivity (Figure 3 C). Moreover, this platform was able to detect three types of 125 EBOV. More recently, Lin et al(Lin et al. 2019) developed a disc chip to detect the four EBOVs using 126 the reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) method (Figure 3 D ).

FIGREF2.text: 138 al. 2016; Kuznetsov et al. 2003; Shourian and Qureshi 2019). More than 37 million people live with 139 HIV and infect about 2 million more every year (Anampa et al. 2020). This has been occurring since 140 the first case of HIV infection in the early 1980s (Bao and Shao 2018). Early HIV diagnosis can reduce 141 transmission through behavioral preventive measures and aid in the treatment of infected individuals 142 through treatment strategies such as anti-retroviral therapies (ART) (Choi et al. 2014). However, only 143 10%~51% of infected individuals are aware they are infected, most of who live in resource-limited 144 areas where they are not able to readily be tested (WHO 2010). Therefore, POC for early diagnosis of 145 HIV is particularly important.

FIGREF3.text: Investigators have applied microfluidics to POC for HIV and achieved encouraging results (Mauk 147 et al. 2017). Glynn et al(Glynn et al. 2014) reported a microfluidic chip based on the number of CD4+ 148 cells and magnetophoresis to detect AIDS (Figure 4 A). This chip uses CD4+ cell numbers to judge 149 HIV infection in the blood and contains a capture efficiency of 93.0 %. It does not need an additional 150 pump and can be operated manually. Liu et al also proposed microfluidic chips based on the number of 151 CD4 + cells as well as immunomagnetic separation to detect HIV infection. However, DNA content 152 was used to quantify CD4+ cells. This chip can obtain accurate results from 10μL of whole blood, 153 which is consist with flow cytometry analysis. Based on the principle of CD4 + cell detection, Alere 154 Pima ™ CD4 was launched in 2010 and provides results within 20 minutes.

FIGREF4.text: 155RT-LAMP is widely used for the detection of HIV RNA in a microfluidic system (Jangam et al.

FIGREF5.text: Sun et al. 2013; Zanoli and Spoto 2013). Damhorst et al (Damhorst et al. 2015) developed a 157 microfluidic platform that integrated RT-LAMP and the smartphone to detect HIV load (Figure 4 B ).

FIGREF6.text: 158Cell lysis buffer combined with a microfluidic chip was used to treat whole blood and complete159 RT-LAMP On-chip. As long as a concentration of 670 viral particles are contained in each microliter of 160 whole blood, the virus can be detected. In more recent studies, Phillips et al(Phillips et al. 2019) 161 engineered an autonomous analysis device (microRAAD) instrument that detects HIV in whole blood 162 (Figure 4 C ). A lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) was used to visualize the product of RT-LAMP. This 163 instrument achieves a limit of detection (LOD) of 100 HIV-1 RNA copies within 90 minutes. Chen et 164 al(Chen et al. 2016) developed a chip that can detect anti-HIV antibodies and HIV RNA,

FIGREF8.text: 181 nucleic acids and antigen-antibody reactions in microfluidic chips. Other methods such as 182 RPA(Crannell et al. 2014; Lillis et al. 2016) and helicase dependent amplification (HDA)(Jordan et al.

FIGREF9.text: 183 2012) are also available in microfluidic chips. These chips demonstrate quicker detection speeds, lower 184 detection limits and more optimal portability when compared to traditional laboratory methods.

FIGREF10.text: However, some chips do not integrate sample preparation and are not suitable for POC. Moreover, 186 based on the presence of a maternal antibody or absence of a host antibody, methods to detect 187 antibodies cannot be used to accurately diagnose HIV early (Rosenberg et al. 2015; Shafiee et al. 2015; 188 Yan et al. 2019). Therefore, more innovative microfluidic technologies need to be developed, 189 specifically ones that are user-friendly and affordable.

FIGREF11.text: virus results in significant morbidity and mortality causing a major public health 192 concern worldwide (Bedford et al. 2015). The virulence of the influenza virus is reflected in the 193 immunogen of its enveloped protein(Kaiser 2006). Infected individuals suffer from severe viral 194 pneumonia and acute lung injury (Guo and Thomas 2017). The WHO estimates that influenza viruses 195 infect approximately 5-15% of the world population and cause 250,000-500,000 deaths each year 196 (Vemula et al. 2016). There are four types of influenza viruses including influenzas A, B, C and D.

FIGREF12.text: Among these, influenza virus A infects humans and other animals such as pigs and birds. Influenza

FIGREF13.text: 198 viruses B and C only infects humans. Influenza virus A can be presented in 144 various subtypes based 199 on combinations of 18 hemagglutinin (HA，H1-H18) and neuraminidase (NA，N1-N11) (Petrova and 200 Russell 2018; Tewawong et al. 2017). To prevent the spread of influenza and reduce economic and 201 health burdens, accurate and rapid detection methods for the virus are necessary.

FIGREF14.text: Anderson et al. 2019; Singh 203 et al. 2017; Vemula et al. 2016; Xu et al. 2010; Zhu et al. 2020). In 2016, Lee's group developed an 204 integrated microfluidic method based on the sandwich-based aptamer that could detect H1N1 at a LOD 205 of 0.032 hemagglutination units (HAU) within 30 minutes (Tseng et al. 2016). In 2020, their group (Lu 206 et al. 2020) also proposed a more automated digital microfluidic platform to detect H1N1 (Figure 5 A ).

FIGREF15.text: within 40 minutes. Ma et al (Ma et al. 2019) proposed a simple self-driven microfluidic 210 chip to detect H1N1 (Figure 5 B). This system integrated nucleic acid extraction and RT-LAMP and 211 was able to detect 3×10 −4 HAU units /reaction in 40 minutes through colorimetric detection. Xia et al 212 (Xia et al. 2019) developed a smartphone-based microfluidic system for the detection of avian 213influenza virus. This system uses gold nanoparticles to detect virus at aLOD of 2.7×10 4 EID 50 /mL.

FIGREF16.text: 214The various characteristics of the multiple influenza virus strains make development of215 microfluidic systems more complicated (Zhang and Miller 2019). More recently, Han et al (Han et al.

FIGREF17.text: NRs) on the inner surface of PDMS. This system can simultaneously detect the H1N1, 219 H5N1 and H7N9 viruses in the 1 pg/ml -10 ng/ml range. Wang et al (Wang et al. 2020) developed a 220 microfluidic system based on magnetism mediated separation and size mediated signal detection to 221 multiplex detect influenza A (Figure 5 C). The LOD of this system reaches 3.4 ng/mL for H7N9 HA 222 and 4.5 ng/mL for H9N2 HA. The disc chip proposed by Liu et al (Liu et al. 2018) can detect three 223 avian influenza viruses and two influenza viruses on a single chip within 70 minutes. Shen et al (Shen 224 et al. 2019) also proposed an integrated microfluidic system that contains sample preparation and a 225 RT-PCR module (Figure 5 D). This system uses glycan-coated magnetic beads to capture all influenza 226 viruses in samples and can simultaneously detect twelve influenza subtypes with LODs ranging from 227 40-3000 copies within 100 minutes. Wu et al (Wu et al. 2019) developed a digital microarray system to 228 multiplex detect H9N2, H1N1 and H7N9 avian influenza viruses. This system uses antibodies to 229 modify the microarray fluorescent magnetic nanospheres to achieve multiplex detection with a LOD of 230 0.02 pg/mL. The commercial product Cobas® has been used for the detection of influenza. This 231 instrument uses qRT-PCR detection, which can detect and distinguish between influenza A and 232 influenza B viruses within 20 minutes using RNA detection of nasopharyngeal swab specimens.

FIGREF18.text: Microfluidic chips have widely focused on the detection of influenza viruses. Both detection time 234 and LOD have significantly improved through this advanced technology. Since there are various 235 subtypes of the influenza viruses, multiplex detection ability of these chips still need improvement.

FIGREF19.text: , portability and cost should be further improved since influenza viruses are common and 238 universal.

FIGREF20.text: Zika virus (ZIKV) 240 ZIKV is a single-stranded, RNA virus that belongs to flaviviridae and is a causative agent of Zika 241 fever (Metz et al. 2019; Qadir et al. 2018). This mosquito-borne virus was identified in 1947 (Nicolini 242 et al. 2017) and 84 countries so far have been affected (Nelson et al. 2019). The WHO has announced 243 that ZIKV is a PHEIC (Xu et al. 2016). ZIKV can be transmitted through human contact and has been 244 detected in urine, blood, semen, amniotic fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva and even tears (Paixao et al.245 2016; Wu et al. 2018). ZIKV infection is generally asymptomatic. A small number of people will have 246 mild clinical symptoms such as mild fever, fatigue, headache, joint pain and a rash, which will rarely 247 lead to serious illness or complications. In recent years, it has been found that the virus can cause 248 teratogenicity and Guillain-Barre syndrome (Cugola et al. 2016; van den Berg et al. 2014). The high 249 contagious rate of the virus led to over 2 million humans being infected globally (Santiago et al. 2018).

FIGREF21.text: The most recent outbreak (Petersen et al. 2016) highlights that early diagnosis of ZIKV is extremely 251 important to control epidemic situations, which is extremely challenging (Janahi et al. 2017; Ricotta et 252 al. 2019).

FIGREF22.text: 254 ZIKV. Microfluidic chips based on nucleic acid detection have important applications in ZIKV 255 detection (Pardee et al. 2016). For example, Song et al (Song et al. 2016) reported a cassette 256 microfluidic system based on RT-LAMP (Figure 6 A). This chip is chemically heated to eliminate the 257 need for electricity. Moreover, it uses a visualization method to observe the virus. These characteristics 258 make this system extremely suitable for POC. This system also achieved detection of 5 plaque-forming 259 units (PFU) in 40 minutes. Ganguli et al (Ganguli et al. 2017) generated a microfluidic chip based on a 260 RT-LAMP and smartphone combination. This chip has the ability to multiplex detect ZIKV and other 261 viruses for precise results. The LOD of this system is 1.56e 5 PFU/mL in blood under 35 minutes. Kaarj 262 et al (Kaarj et al. 2018) developed a paper microfluidic chip combined with RT-LAMP and a 263 smartphone to detect ZIKV RNA. This system is sensitive and can detect 1 copy/μL in 15 minutes with 264 high specificity. However, this system requires additional purification steps. Yang et al (Yang et al.265 2019) proposed a wearable microfluidic system to detect the Zika virus (Figure 6 B). This system 266 integrates RPA on a bandage-like sensor. Body heat can activate the sensor since the RPA can react at 267 room temperature. It has also been demonstrated that the wearable biosensor reaches a detection limit 268 of 10 copies/μL within 10 minutes. This method has proven to be very convenient, low-cost and 269 easy-to-receive. If equipped with a sample preparation function in the future, it will have very broad 270 application value. More recently, Batule et al(Batule et al. 2020) reported a two-step paper chip 271 strategy used for RNA extraction and RT-LAMP. This method can detect 10 copies in the serum within 272 1 hour.273On-chip immunological testing remains an important diagnostic measure for Zika virus infection.

FIGREF23.text: Draz et al (Draz et al. 2018) reported a paper chip that used platinum nanoparticles. The platinum 275 nanoparticles used antibodies on paper that improved sensitivity and specificity. This chip was able to 276 detect ZIKV with a LOD of 10 1 copies/μl. Rong et al (Rong et al. 2019) developed a paper microfluidic 277 system based on quantum dot probes and smartphones. This chip shows limited cross-reactivity with 278 other viruses and can reach a LOD of 0.15 ng mL -1 in serum within 20 minutes. Meena et al (Meena et 279 al. 2018) developed an optofluidic chip based on magnetic beads and optical detection to 280 simultaneously detect ZIKV nucleic acids and proteins. This method contained a LOD of 8 fm and 281 ruled out potential interference from other viruses.

FIGREF24.text: Microfluidic technology has provided a new route for the detection of ZIKV. Although qRT-PCR 283 is still the gold standard for ZIKV detection, microfluidics has shown fast and accurate advantages and 284 continued development will demonstrate their practical utility in response to ZIVK outbreaks. In285 addition, compared to other viruses such as EBOV and the influenza virus, ZIKV does not have 286 multiple subtypes. However, to date, ZIKV infection is still difficult to diagnose because of its 287 cross-reactivity with other flaviviruses, such as dengue virus (Wu et al. 2018). Therefore, in the 288 continued development of improved microfluidic methods, the detection of other flaviviruses or 289 arboviruses need to be ruled out for cross-reactivity (Chang et al. 2017).

FIGREF25.text: Dengue virus (DENV)291DENV is a mosquito-borne virus that causes dengue fever (DF), dengue hemorrhagic fever and292 dengue shock syndrome (DSS) (Lang et al. 2016; Nakhapakorn and Tripathi 2005). DENV belongs to 293 the flaviviridae group and has four serotypes (DENV1-4)(Zonetti et al. 2018). Dengue fever usually 294 has a 10-day incubation period. Patients usually have typical symptoms such as fever, severe headache, 295 postophthalmic pain, muscle and joint pain, a rash, nausea, abdominal pain and swollen glands (Adimy 296 et al. 2020; Chan and Johansson 2012; Halstead 2008). Currently, the main detection methods used in 297 laboratories for dengue virus rely on cell culture, PCR and ELISA assays. These time time-consuming, 298 low sensitivity methods cannot quickly respond to DENV outbreaks (Suthanthiraraj et al. 2019).

FIGREF26.text: Microfluidic based methods can give more precise and efficient results compared to300 electrochemical methods for the early detection of DENV (Eivazzadeh-Keihan et al. 2019). Recently, 301 Yoo et al (Yoo et al. 2020) proposed a microfluidic system that integrated direct sample preparation and 302 LAMP to detect dengue virus

FIGREF27.text: 308 detected 100 RNA copies per mL of plasma within 90minutes. Choi et al (Choi et al. 2017) developed a 309 paper chip that applied agarose into paper to achieve flow control and improve detection sensitivity 310 (Figure 7 C). Moreover, this chip integrated RNA extraction and RT-LAMP to detect DENV RNA in 311 blood samples. Using this chip, DENV RNA was detected at 50 RNA copies.

FIGREF28.text: Non-structural protein 1 (NS1) antigen detection was universally used in serological tests for 313 DENV. NS1 is a highly conserved glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 45-55 kDa(Lai et al. 2019).

FIGREF29.text: immunological tests on chip, Hosseini et al (Hosseini et al. 2015) fabricated a disk chip equipped 315 with polymethacrylate microspheres and microballoon mixing systems. This chip can manipulate 54 316 samples in parallel and can detect 1.9 pfu/mL in serum. A dielectrophoresis chip was also proposed by 317 Iswardy et al (Iswardy et al. 2017) (Figure 7 D). A dielectrophoresis force was used in this chip to 318 capture beads and an immunoreaction was used to capture the virus. This chip only requires 5 minutes 319 to detect the virus with a LOD of 10 4 PFU/mL from 15 μL samples. Yu-zoon et al (Yuzon et al. 2019) 320 generated a paper chip using cellulose acetate film and a nitrocellulose membrane to detect the NS1 321 antigen. This chip reached a LOD 84.66 ng/mL in 2 minutes.

FIGREF30.text: Microfluidics can be regarded as a capable candidate of POC for DENV. Since DENV easily 323 cross-reacts with ZIKV, multiplex and precise detection in microfluidics should be improved. Moreover,324the four serotypes of DENV should be considered when novel chips are developed in the future.

FIGREF31.text: 21st century, two highly pathogenic human coronaviruses including Severe Acute327 Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 328 (MERS-CoV) have emerged and triggered global pandemics that resulted in high morbidity and 329 mortality. COVID-19 is also a type of coronavirus that belongs to the β-Coronavirus(Kim et al. 2020).

FIGREF32.text: Currently, COVID-19, which is caused by the severe acute SARS-CoV-2, poses a major threat to 331 human health as well as economies world-wide. SARS-CoV-2 is believed to infect host cells through 332 the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), resulting in COVID-19. SARS-CoV-2 has a stronger 333 transmission capacity compared to SARS and has a similar pathogenicity compared to334 MERS-COV(Zheng et al. 2020). COVID-19 symptoms include a dry cough, fatigue and fever that is 335 followed by anorexia, myalgia and dyspnea. In addition, COVID-19 can also cause damage to the 336 myocardium, resulting in chronic cardiovascular issues (Li et al. 2020; Zheng et al. 2020

FIGREF33.text: 356 nucleic acid amplification and detection into a small detection kit, where even those without 357 professional skills can perform complex molecular detection analyses. This system has been used for 358 the detection of HIV. In response to COVID-19, Xpert SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid detection reagent has 359 obtained EVA from FDA for the qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid. RTisochip ® 360 proposed by CapitalBio TM in China can detect 6 common respiratory viruses including COVID-19 in a 361 single chip within 1.5 hours. This system not only detects SARS-CoV-2, but also effectively identifies 362 patients with influenza and COVID-19. The POC instrument developed by Cannon TM in Japan can 363 detect the SARS-CoV-2 in 35 minutes. The instrument only weighs 2.4 kg and DNA can be amplified 364 in as little as 10 minutes using respiratory samples.365 Microfluidic technology can both be automated and miniaturized to detect viruses. This advanced 366 technology in POC will change current medical methods. Compared to the SARS-CoV and 367 MERS-CoV outbreaks, lab on a chip has played a crucial role in the COVID-19 outbreak. Countries 368 including the USA, China and Japan have approved the use of this technology, which fully 369 demonstrates the application value of lab on a chip in POC.

FIGREF34.text: Other representative viruses 371 HBV is highly contagious and spreads through bodily fluids such as blood, saliva and semen.372 HBV infection can cause cirrhosis, liver failure or hepatocellular carcinoma (Estevez et al. 2017; 373 Lavanchy 2004; Sarrazin 2016).Investigators also use microfluidics to perform convenient and accurate 374 diagnoses for these viruses (Chang et al. 2015; Vaghi et al. 2016). Li et al(Li et al. 2019b) described a 375 disc chip to detect HBV in whole blood. This disc chip integrated sample preparation and qRT-PCR.

FIGREF35.text: This chip has 120576 reaction chambers and the dynamic range of the detection template is up to 381 6 orders of magnitude. The maximum detectable template amount is 1.13 × 10 6 copy numbers in 36 382 μL(Wu et al. 2017). Hepatitis C (HCV) is the major cause of chronic liver disease and is often 383 associated with the development of liver cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, liver failure and death 384 (Pawlotsky 2016; Petruzziello et al.). Mu et al (Mu et al. 2014) developed a paper chip to detect 385 HCV(Figure 8 A). This method was based on the detection IgG antibodies against HCV and an 8-plex 386 paper chip was designed to yield additional information about the HCV infection. On this chip, 267 387 amol was detected using chemiluminescence and 26.7 fmol was detected using colorimetry.

FIGREF36.text: 394method, the amplification of nucleic acid is not needed. The LOD of this system is 1pm in 2 hours and 395 100 fM in 24 hours. Ye et al(Ye et al. 2019) proposed a portable disc system(Figure 8 B)to detect the 396 ASFV using a circular fluorescent probe-mediated isothermal nucleic acid amplification (CFPA) 397 method. This system has a LOD of 10 copies/μL and 100% specificity for pig samples in 10.8 minutes.

FIGREF37.text: Challenges in using microfluidics for viral detection 399 3.1 Integrated sample preparation 400 Sample preparation is crucial for precise virus detection. Microfluidic systems even have quicker 401 and more accurate advantages compared to traditional methods when it comes to virus outbreaks, 402 where many of these methods ignore sample preparation, which is not suitable for POC. In addition, 403 compared to other detection objects, nano-level and RNA-coded viruses pose greater challenges for 404 sample preparation. In recent years, virus sample preparation has also attracted more attention and 405 there have been different proposals for viral sample preparation strategies. For different detection 406 methods, sample preparation have different meanings such as sample enrichment (Surawathanawises et 407 al. 2016) or nucleic acid extraction (Chen et al. 2019; Zhang et al. 2019). Recently, Du et al(Du et al.408 2017a) proposed an automated sample preparation microfluidic system that utilized air bubbles and 409 magnetic beads to achieve efficient capture of the Ebola virus. Vaghi et al (Vaghi et al. 2016) reported a 410 PDMS chip for HCV RNA purification and detection from plasma. Capture efficiency was improved 411 with two orders of magnitude and LOD was improved 10-fold using this system. Kim et al (Kim et al.412 2019) proposed a microfluidic system to concentrate viral particles. In this system, the poly (ethylene 413 glycol) methacrylate (PEGMA) membrane was integrated into the chip and the virus was concentrated 414 through autonomous and continuous perfusion. Yeh et al(Yeh et al. 2020)developed a microfluidic chip 415 for rapid virus capture and in situ detection. This chip uses carbon nanotube arrays with differential 416 filtration porosity to concentrate the virus and uses surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) to 417 detect the virus. This research demonstrates that an effective virus sample preparation method in chip 418

FIGREF38.text: High throughput and multiplex detection 429 Virus outbreaks are characterized by a rapid spread and large scale infection. For example, DENV 11 causes 50-100 million infections, with ~2.5% of individuals passing away (Yu et al. studies have shown that when there is a viral outbreak, increased deaths are due to a large 436 number of infections, not increased toxicity (Harris et al. 2008). Therefore, microfluidic chips used for 437 clinically-oriented virus detection face a throughput challenge. 438 Multiplex detection can improve the accuracy of early detection (Seok et al. 2017) and give 439 additional details for infected patients (Goktas and Sirin 2016) since most viruses have various 440 subtypes and pathogenicity. However, many studies have ignored the fact that there are virus subtypes 441 and only target one or more subtypes, which affects accuracy in practical applications. For example, 442 some viruses such as influenza virus have nearly 200 subtypes, which poses a great challenge for 443 microfluidic chip. To achieve multiple detection in chips, multiple colors or different division areas are 444 used (Gu et al. 2018; Pang et al. 2018; Yan et al. 2017; Zhang et al. 2016). However, these methods 445 generally need expensive instrument and reagents, which limit the application of the chip. Therefore, 446 multiple detection capabilities are challenges in the clinical application of microfluidic chip.

FIGREF39.text: of microfluidic technology makes "sample-in-answer-out" possible for virus 449 detection. Most research and commercial products obtain results according to the standard curve, which 450 is a relative quantitative method. This type of quantitative method is often limited by several factors 451 including inhibitors and amplification efficiency (Bian et al. 2015). Digital quantitative methods such 452 as digital PCR and digital LAMP can achieve absolute quantification and do not depend on the 453 standard curve to obtain high sensitivity (Sreejith et al. 2018). Recently, studies have shown the 454 accuracy of digital quantitative methods and this emerged technology has been widely used in clinical 455 diagnoses (Salipante and Jerome 2019; Tian et al. 2015; Yin et al. 2019). However, due to limitations 456 related to instruments, costs and sample preparation, it is difficult to apply this quantitative method in 457POCT. Therefore, the use of digital quantitative methods such as digital RPA and digital Elisa to 458 achieve "sample-in-digital-answer-out" results pose great challenges in virus detection.

FIGREF40.text: review, viral outbreaks were introduced as well as a discussion of the advantages and 461 disadvantages of various microfluidic systems in response to these viruses. These life-threatening 462 viruses have different characteristics that influence different microfluidic chips in early virus detection.

FIGREF41.text: delivered to those who 480 need it (Blacksell 2012; Huppert et al. 2010; Tenforde et al. 2019) will be readily available. To apply 481 microfluidic chips clinically, professional users can use microfluidic technology with simple operations 482 and detect a large number of samples in a short time while obtaining accurate information. Early 483 detection of viruses using microfluidic technology can help reduce the scale of viral outbreaks and 484 improve response to infection.

TABREF0.text: and Liu (Zhao and Liu 168 2016) proposed a paper electrochemical microfluidic system for the diagnosis of an HIV/HCV 169 co-infection. This paper system contains multi-channels and uses ELISA to detect antibodies in serum 170 samples. This system can detect 300 pg/ml HIV and 750 pg/ml Hepatitis C virus (HCV) within 20 minutes. Kurdekar et al(Kurdekar et al. 2016) use carbon dots, Whatman filter paper and nitrocellulose 172 paper to detect the HIV antigen. Results suggest that assays using nitrocellulose paper have higher 173 detection ranges (10 μg/mL to 250 pg/mL) and sensitivities (fourfold) compared to assays using Whatman filter paper. Li et al (Li and Liu 2016)(Figure 4 D ) developed an origami nanobiosensor 175 based on paper and zinc oxide nanowires (ZnO NWs) to detect HIV. ZnO NWs was used to increase 176 the surface area of electrodes as well as binding capacity. This biosensor utilizes an electrochemical 177impedance spectroscopy (EIS) method to achieve a LOD of 60 fg mL −1 . In addition, OraQuick®, 178 developed by OraSure Technologies TM , can detect the HIV antibodies in saliva and the specificity can

TABREF1.text: testing as the gold standard for virus detection. Antibody testing is used as a supplementary test for suspected cases where nucleic acid detection was negative and is not used as a basis for initial diagnosis or exclusion of new coronavirus infection.To detect the virus, qRT-PCR is still used as the mainstream detection method. However, due to the rapid development of the epidemic, qRT-PCR can no longer meet the demands associated with needed testing. POC instruments that based on the microfluidic technology play important roles in diagnosing the virus during this epidemic. For example, The ID NOW ® instrument proposed by Abbott TM in USA can detect positive samples in 5 minutes and negative results in 13 minutes. This product has received emergency use authorization (EUA) from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration 349 (FDA). The detection principle is based on the RPA technology and the instrument only weighs 3 kg, which is very suitable for POC. Filmarray ® , a product of BioFire TM , uses microfluidic technology that integrates nucleic acid extraction, purification and PCR amplification into a single chip and results in sequential and accurate detection. This instrument has been previously used for the detection of EBOV.Currently, the COVID-19 test kit has been approved by the FDA for EUA based on this system and can Filmarray ® Torch platforms. GeneXpert ® developed by Cepheid TM can integrate sample preparation,

Virulence can be divided into high, moderate, low and without clinical symptoms. High virulence ASFV can lead to the rapid death of

back_matter.text: The performance of microfluidic systems in virus detection are discussed and analyzed The challenges of microfluidic systems with regard to sample preparation, throughput, and multiplexing are highlighted Ideas for future development of microfluidic systems were proposed.
